questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to a dental clinic for a dental procedure. The dentist administers lignocaine to the patient and starts the procedure. The patient suddenly complains of headache, fatigue, breathlessness and chest discomfort. The dentist also noticed that blood oozing from his gums was chocolate brown, and the patient appeared cyanosed. What is the treatment in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methylene blue The given clinical picture is suggestive of methemoglobinemia.

Highyeild:

Factors that are responsible for causing methemoglobinemia are: Local anaesthetics like lignocaine, prilocaine, benzocaine Sulpha drugs Nitroglycerin Nitroprusside Methemoglobinemia is due to the accumulation of fe3+ion. Its characteristic feature is chocolate brown colour blood. cyanosis is also present. spo2 is around 85% Methylene blue is the treatment of methemoglobinemia In our body fe3+ produced is converted to fe2+ with the help of cytochrome b5 reductase enzyme by using NADH. But any oxidative stress or any of the drugs mentioned above inactivates this enzyme and causes accumulation of fe3+ Methylene blue with the help of NADPH methamo-reductase enzyme converts fe3+ to fe2+.

Hydroxocobalamin is used in the treatment of Vit B12 deficiency anaemia and not in methemoglobinemia Option: D. Nitroprusside is used in the treatment of acute hypertension

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Co poisoning and treatment is hyperbaric oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning and treatment is dmsa

questions.correct_answer: C. Co poisoning and treatment is hyperbaric oxygen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Co poisoning and treatment is hyperbaric oxygen The picture above shows cherry red discolouration which is characteristically seen in co-poisoning. the given history of fire in the home and similar clinical features in family members also favour diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Co has a higher affinity to hb than oxygen. therefore there is a left shift of the O2-hb dissociation curve.co combines with hb and forms carboxy hb. this causes a decrease in oxygen delivery to tissues. carboxyhb is cherry red and masks the development of cyanosis associated with poor oxygen delivery to tissues. Co-poisoning is more dangerous than methemoglobinemia because the former blocks the electron transport chain and utilisation of dissolved oxygen is blocked. Treatment is with hyperbaric oxygen.

Option: Cyanide poisoning also interferes with cellular respiration. hydroxocobalamin is the antidote. Option: Lead poisoning is characterised by facial pallor, anaemia, constipation and encephalopathy. DMSA is the antidote.

If the patient's symptoms are caused by acute respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following parameters is likely to be normal?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Capillary wedge pressure The normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is between 4 to 12 mmHg. Elevated levels of PCWP might indicate severe left ventricular failure or severe mitral stenosis Increased pulmonary artery pressure may indicate a left-to-right cardiac shunt, pulmonary artery hypertension, COPD or emphysema, pulmonary embolus, pulmonary edema, or left ventricular failure.

Highyeild:

The patient's signs and symptoms suggest ards for which sepsis is a major risk factor. One of the criteria of ards is the absence of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which means that pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is usually normal An elevated wedge pressure is suggestive of a cardiogenic cause such as pulmonary hypertension Ards are characterised by diffuse injury to pulmonary vascular endothelium resulting in increased pulmonary capillary permeability ( Option: C ) and leaky alveolocapillary membrane. The interstitial and intra-alveolar edema, inflammation and hyaline membrane formation cause lung compliance to decrease ( Option: B ), work of breathing to increase ( Option: A) and oxygen diffusion capacity to decrease

questions.text: A 64-year-old chronic smoker with dyspnoea, nonproductive cough and tachypnoea. on physical examination, the patient assumes a tripod position and has pursed lip breathing. The chest appears barrel in shape and an expiratory wheeze is heard on auscultation. all of the following findings would be seen in his pulmonary function tests except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal residual volume The given clinical scenario is suggestive of emphysema.

Highyeild:

During expiration, alveoli are partially opened because of surfactant and because of elastic fibres which apply traction to keep the airway open In the case of chronic smokers and alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency, there is increased elastase and the elastic fibres get damaged. due to this airways close early during expiration and air is trapped in the there is progressive accumulation of air in the alveoli and more air trapping. As time progresses there is decreased airway radius and increased airway resistance. There is an increase in ap diameter due to more air trapping and causing a barrel-shaped chest. All the lung volumes increase in emphysema: increase in rv, frv and tlc. Emphysema is an obstructive lung disease and there is a decrease in fev1/fvc. Vital capacity decreases as the severity of emphysema increases

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presented in ed with c/o headache, shortness of breath and chest discomfort for 5 days. Hypoventilation In the above scenario the patient presents with features of hypoxemia which is most probably due to decreased respiratory effort due to the neuromuscular disease. the alveoli-arteriolar gradient is decreased in hypoventilation due to decreased respiratory effort which further causes a decrease in pao2. Since there is no diffusion defect arterial pao2 is unaffected.

questions.text: Carbon monoxide diffusion capacity decreases in all, except: You see a male patient in your clinic for respiratory complaints and advise pulmonary function test which shows reduced Carbon monoxide diffusion capacity. Which of the following would you rule out as a cause for his complaints?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alveolar haemorrhage Single Breath DLCO Study for Diffusion Capacity:-

Highyeild:

The diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is reduced in all patients with intrinsic lung disorders. The DLCO is not affected in patients with Extraparenchymal restrictive lung diseases i.e. restrictive lung diseases caused due to chest wall or muscular disorders. A normal DLCO value in restrictive diseases excludes intrinsic lung disease and indicates extrinsic lung disorders due to chest wall pleura or neuromuscular lung disease. The DLCO is the most sensitive parameter and findings may be abnormal even when the lung volumes are preserved in mild intrinsic lung disease In obstructive lung diseases, the transfer capacity of the lung is not affected.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient was undergoing a laparotomy for which the anaesthetist gave nitric oxide as an induction agent. After some time, the patient started desaturating despite adequate oxygenation. When blood samples are drawn for testing, what colour would be expected on examination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chocolate brown Methemoglobinemia

Highyeild:

The binding of oxygen to methemoglobin results in an increased affinity of oxygen to the three other heme sites (that are still ferrous) within the same tetrameric haemoglobin unit. This leads to an overall reduced ability of the red blood cell to release oxygen to tissues, with the associated oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve, therefore, shifted to the left. When methemoglobin concentration is elevated in red blood cells, tissue hypoxia can occur. Causes:- 1. Congenital 2. Acquired methemoglobinemia

Random:

The explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A. Blue colour is not seen in methemoglobinemia and it is a factual error Option: B. Bright Red colour is usually seen in normal individuals with a steady flow and indicates fresh blood Option: D. Green colour blood is seen in a rare condition known as sulfhemglobinemia Methemoglobinemia is a disorder characterized by the presence of a higher-than-normal level of methemoglobin (metHb, i.e., ferric [Fe3+] rather than ferrous [Fe2+] haemoglobin) in the blood. Methemoglobin is a form of haemoglobin that contains ferric [Fe3+] iron and has a decreased ability to bind oxygen. However, ferrous iron has an increased affinity for bound oxygen.

Extraedge:

a. Dapsone b. Bismuth nitrates c. Antibiotics (trimethoprim, sulfonamides and dapsone), d. Local Anesthetics (especially articaine and prilocaine), e. Aniline dyes, f. Metoclopramide Normal blood (left) and chocolate-colored blood of methemoglobinemia (right). Symptoms Signs and symptoms of methemoglobinemia (methemoglobin >1%) include shortness of breath, cyanosis, mental status changes, headache, fatigue, exercise intolerance, dizziness and loss of consciousness. Arterial blood with elevated methemoglobin levels has a characteristic chocolate-brown colour (LQ 2012) as compared to normal bright red oxygen-containing arterial blood. In advanced cases hypotension, dysrhythmias, seizures, coma and death can occur. Treatment Methemoglobinemia can be treated with supplemental oxygen and methylene blue

Highyeild:

1. It is defined as hypoxia (PaO2 <60 mmHg) with a normal or low PaCO2. 2. It is caused primarily by ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch. PAo2 – Pao2 (Pulmonary Alveolar & Pulmonary arteriolar oxygen gradient) is increased It is a diffusion or perfusion defect due to i. Parenchymal disease (V/Q mismatch) ii. The disease of blood vessels = Pulmonary embolism iii. Interstitial Lung Diseases (ARDS) Causes: Pneumonia Pulmonary oedema Pulmonary Embolism Asthma ARDS. 2. Type II respiratory failure a. It is defined as hypoxia (PaO, <60 mmHg) with hypercapnia (PaCO2 is >45 mmHg). b. This is caused by alveolar hypoventilation, with or without V/Q mismatch. PAoz - Paoz is Normal Causes: COPD (Chronic bronchitis is the commonest cause) Q (LQ 2015) , obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA). Reduced respiratory drive: sedative drugs, CNS tumour, or trauma. Neuromuscular disease: cervical cord lesion, diaphragmatic paralysis, poliomyelitis, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barre syndrome. Thoracic wall disease: flail chest, kyphoscoliosis

questions.text: Which of the following can be a feature of shock lung?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse alveolar damage {Acute lung injury = Shock lung = Diffuse Alveolar Damage = Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema = HAPE (High Altitude Pulmonary Edema)

Highyeild:

ARDS is a clinical syndrome caused by diffuse alveolar-capillary damage. It is characterized clinically by the rapid onset of severe life-threatening respiratory insufficiency, cyanosis, and severe arterial hypoxemia that is refractory to oxygen therapy and may progress to extrapulmonary multisystem organ failure. Chest radiographs show diffuse alveolar infiltration. Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) is the histologic manifestation. (Robins, 7th edition, page no 715) ARDS, or acute lung injury, is caused by direct lung injury or occurs secondary to severe systemic illness. Lung damage and release of inflammatory mediators cause increased capillary permeability and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema often accompanied by multiorgan failure.

Bronchiolitis -it is the inflammation of bronchioles and the bronchi and no features of shock lung

Extraedge:

Causes: - Pulmonary: (Direct lung injury) Pneumonia; Gastric aspiration Toxic gas inhalation Lung injury; Vasculitis; Lung Contusion. Others: (Indirect lung injury) Shock; Septicemia; Haemorrhage; Multiple transfusions: DIC; Pancreatitis; Acute liver failure; Trauma; Head injury; Malaria; Fat embolism; Burns; Obstetric events (eclampsia; amniotic fluid embolus); Drugs/toxin ( heroin ). Cardiopulmonary bypass with the heart-lung machine Clinical physiology of ARDS: - Clinical history of insult known to cause ARDS there is a sudden onset of dyspnea This is a clue to the Accumulation of proteinaceous pulmonary edema in the interstitium. The diagnosis of ARDS is made on clinical grounds on the following criteria: - Acute onset Bilateral pulmonary infiltrate on chest X-ray. Pulmonary artery wedge pressure < 18mm/Hg (i.e. LA pressure is normal). A partial pressure of arterial oxygen to fractional inspired oxygen concentration (PaO2/FiO2) <200mmHg. ARDS X-ray and CT scan. (bilateral diffuse infilrates)

questions.explanation:

Hypotension

The explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A. Fever -oral temperature greater than 38 C or hypothermia less than 36 C is seen in SIRS Option: B. Tachypnea-breaths greater than 24 /min is seen in SIRS Option: C. Leukopenia less than 4000/ml is seen in SIRS Definitions used to describe the condition of septic patients Bacteremia Presence of bacteria in the blood, as evidenced by positive blood cultures Septicemia Presence of microbes or their toxins in the blood Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) (May be infectious or non-infectious etiology) Two or more of the following conditions 1. Fever (oral temperature >38°C) or hypothermia (<36°C) 2. Tachypnea (>24 breaths/min) 3. Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats/min) 4. Leukocytosis (>12,000/mL), leukopenia (<4000/mL), or >10% bands; may have a noninfectious etiology. Sepsis SIRS that have a proven or suspected microbial etiology Severe sepsis (similar to sepsis syndrome) Sepsis with one or more signs of organ dysfunction - for example: 1. Cardiovascular: BP 590 mmHg or mean arterial pressure 570 mmHg that responds to the administration of Intravenous fluid. 2. Renal: Urine output <0.5 mL/kg per hour for 1h despite adequate fluid resuscitation 3. Respiratory: Pao:/Floz $250 or, if the lung is the only dysfunctional organ, $200. 4. Hematologic: Platelet count <80,000/mL 5. Unexplained metabolic acidosis: 6. Adequate fluid resuscitation: Pulmonary artery wedge pressure ≥12 mmHg or central venous pressure 28 mmHg. Septic shock Sepsis with hypotension BP <90 mmHg systolic or 40 mmHg less than the patient's normal blood pressure for at least 1 h despite adequate fluid resuscitation; or Need for vasopressors to maintain systolic blood pressure 290 mmHg or mean arterial pressure 270 mmHg Refractory septic shock The septic shock that lasts for 1 h and does not respond to fluid or pressor administration. Multiple-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) Dysfunction of more than one organ, requiring intervention to maintain hemostasis.
